data.Name: Area
data.Description: Represents the 2D area delineated by the lateral extent of the reservoir or  stratigraphic interval containing fluids of interest.

data.Name: Permeability Average
data.Description: The average permeability found in the reservoir facies of this lithostratigraphic unit.; Measured average permeability for this interval. This may come from core or sidewall core, or it may be estimated from logs. This field may be either the average of all permeability measurements made on this sample, or it may be used when only one measurement is available. The average permeability in the netted portion of the interval.

data.Name: Pyrolysis Bulk Hydrogen Index Average
data.Description: The hydrogen index (HI) represents the amount of hydrogen relative to the amount of organic carbon present in a sample. The S2 curve of a Rock-Eval analysis can help us determine the total amount of hydrogen in milligrams of hydrogen to grams of sample according to the following formula: HI=(S2/TOC)X100.

data.Name: Pyrolysis Bulk Oxygen Index Average
data.Description: The oxygen index (OI) represents the amount of oxygen relative to the amount of organic carbon present in a sample.

data.Name: Aquifer Strength Type ID
data.Description: Represents the aquifer pressure support strength or behaviour to hydrocarbon recovery.

data.Name: Pyrolysis Bulk Productivity Index Average
data.Description: Rock Evaluation Production Index (PI) calculated as S1/(S1 + S2). Represents free fraction of total potential HCs. May be related to maturity. Helps ID staining and contamination. In the case where there are multiple measurements of PI, the intent is an average of these measurements or the definitive PI to represent PI.

data.Name: Pyrolysis Bulk Temperature Average Maximum
data.Description: Average of measured Tmax values from bulk pyrolysis. Tmax is the temperature at which the maximum release of hydrocarbons from cracking of kerogen occurs during pyrolysis (top of S2 peak). Tmax is an indication of the stage of maturation of the organic matter.

data.Name: Dip Angle Average
data.Description: The average dip angle is the average angle, at the middle of the hydrocarbon accumulation, at which the reservoir bedding plane declines away from the horizontal.

data.Name: Porosity Effective Average
data.Description: The average fraction of porosity (ratio of void space to bulk volume of rock containing that void space) that contributes to flow, found in the reservoir segment.

data.Name: Thickness True Stratigraphic Average Gross
data.Description:
The average gross thickness is the average true stratigraphic gross thickness of the hydrocarbon-bearing reservoir rock within the reservoir including net and non-net reservoir rock.
The average gross thickness of the interval of interest (zone, geobody, reservoir, field, basin, etc.), including rock that does not meet the cut-off criteria.

data.Name: Permeability Horizontal Average
data.Description: This is the permeability of the reservoir measured in a direction parallel to the reservoir bedding plane (this may not always be horizontal with respect to the earth).

data.Name: Water Saturation Initial Average
data.Description: The initial water saturation (SWi) is the fraction of formation water in an undisturbed reservoir with no prior production from any earlier well. The saturation is known as the total water saturation if the pore space is the total porosity, but is known as effective water saturation if the pore space is the effective porosity.

data.Name: Gas Maturity Average
data.Description: It is a measure of the process of a source rock becoming capable of generating gas when exposed to appropriate pressures and temperatures.

data.Name: Oil Maturity Average
data.Description: It is a measure of the process of a source rock becoming capable of generating oil when exposed to appropriate pressures and temperatures.

data.Name: Pay Thickness True Vertical Average Net
data.Description: Represents the net hydrocarbon thickness in the reservoir. Usually calculated by multiplying ReservoirGrossThickness * NetToGrossRatio * Porosity * HydrocarbonSaturation.

data.Name: Thickness True Vertical Average Net
data.Description: The average net thickness is the average true vertical net thickness of the hydrocarbon-bearing (sand) reservoir rock within the reservoir segment. The avg. net thick = avg. gross thick * net gross ratio.

data.Name: Oil Rim Thickness True Vertical Average
data.Description: It is the average true vertical thickness of the oil part of gas/oil or oil/gas/condensate deposit, the size and geological reserves of which are significantly smaller than of the gas part of the two-phase deposits.

data.Name: Oil Viscosity Average
data.Description: Oil viscosity is a measure of the resistance to flow exerted by the oil, and is given in units of centipoise (cP). Higher values indicate greater resistance to flow.

data.Name: Pay Permeability Average
data.Description: The average permeability within the pay sections of the reservoir/zone. The pay sections are typically hydrocarbon pores of the reservoir as deduced from porosity, water saturation, and sand cut-offs.

data.Name: Reservoir Permeability Average
data.Description: The average permeability within the reservoir sections of the reservoir/zone. The reservoir sections are typically deduced from V-shale and porosity cut-offs.

data.Name: Sand Permeability Average
data.Description: The average permeability within the sand sections of the reservoir. The sand sections are typically deduced from V-shale cut-offs.

data.Name: Porosity Average
data.Description: The average porosity is the average fraction porosity (ratio of void space to bulk volume of rock containing that void space) found in the reservoir rock. This quantity is the interpreted bulk porosity of the reservoir and is not corrected for water saturation.

data.Name: Pay Porosity Average
data.Description: The average porosity within the pay sections of the reservoir/zone. The pay sections are typically hydrocarbon pores of the reservoir as deduced from porosity, water saturation, and sand cut-offs.

data.Name: Reservoir Porosity Average
data.Description: The average porosity within the reservoir sections of the reservoir/zone. The reservoir sections are typically deduced from V-shale and porosity cut-offs.

data.Name: Sand Porosity Average
data.Description: The average porosity within the sand sections of the reservoir. The sand sections are typically deduced from V-shale cut-offs.

data.Name: Rock Compressibility Average
data.Description: This is the average rock compressibility for the rock within this reservoir. Rock compressibility is expressed in units of Pore Volume change per unit Pore Volume per unit pressure change.

data.Name: Rock Maturity Average
data.Description: The maturity of a source rock reflects the ambient pressure and temperature as well as the duration of conditions favorable for hydrocarbon generation. Used as an indicator of its hydrocarbon potential.

data.Name: Thickness True Vertical Average Gross
data.Description: The average gross thickness is the average true vertical gross thickness of the hydrocarbon-bearing reservoir rock within the reservoir including net and non-net reservoir rock.

data.Name: Permeability Vertical Average
data.Description: This is the average permeability of the reservoir measured in the direction perpendicular to the reservoir bedding plane (may not be true vertical with respect to the earth).

data.Name: Vitrinite Vitrinite Reflectance Average
data.Description: Vitrinite reflectance is a measure of the percentage of incident light reflected from the surface of vitrinite particles in a sedimentary rock. It is referred to as %Ro. Results are often presented as a mean Ro value based on all vitrinite particles measured in an individual sample.

data.Name: Bubblepoint Pressure
data.Description: Bubble-point pressure is defined as the pressure at which the first bubble of gas begins to come out of solution at a specific temperature and form bubbles.

data.Name: Bubblepoint Temperature
data.Description: The bubble point temperature is the temperature at which vapor first forms from a liquid. When the liquid reaches its bubble point temperature, vapor is formed and this vapor bubbles through the liquid. Bubble point is the temperature at which the saturated liquid starts to boil off its first bubble of vapor.

data.Name: Carbon Dioxide Content
data.Description: Average Carbon Dioxide (CO2 mole % in Gas) content in a reservoir or field.

data.Name: Dewpoint Pressure
data.Description: The pressure where an incipient liquid phase condenses from a gas phase.

data.Name: Water Saturation Effective
data.Description: Petrophysicists define two porosities, the total porosity (PHIT) that includes isolated pores and the space occupied by clay-bound water and the effective porosity (PHIE) which excludes isolated pores and pore volume occupied by water adsorbed on clay minerals. The effective Sw is similarly defined, i.e. Sw in interconnected pore space.

data.Name: Total Organic Carbon Estimated Maximum
data.Description: Different methods used to estimate the Total Organic Carbon such as delta log r to assess the potential for organic matter to generate hydrocarbons (such as oil and gas) under certain geological and thermal conditions expressed in a ratio of weight percent organic carbon to total rock sample.

data.Name: Stratigraphic Column Rank Unit Type ID
data.Description: The reference value type defining a column position in a stratigraphic chart, which is ordered by rank. The rank and relative magnitudes of the units in the chronostratigraphic hierarchy are a function of the length of time interval that their rocks extend.

data.Name: Isolated Interval Type ID
data.Description: Well completion is the process of making a well ready for production (or injection) after drilling operations. Completions can be divided into three categories: open hole completions, liner completions, and perforated casing completions.

data.Name: Deposition Mode ID
data.Description: in RESQML Deposition mode: proportional between top and bottom, parallel to bottom, parallel to top, parallel to another boundary.

data.Name: Development Stage ID
data.Description: Phase of the value chain to which the referring item has been associated with, e.g., Exploration, Field Development, Production or Late Life.

data.Name: Salinity
data.Description: The salt content or concentration of water present in underground formations or reservoirs.

data.Name: Primary Environment Of Deposition ID
data.Description: A depositional environment is the accumulation of chemical, biological, and physical properties and processes associated with the deposition of sediments that lead to a distinctive suite of sedimentary rocks. When there are multiple environments of deposition, it is the most volumetrically abundant.

data.Name: Facies Type
data.Description: The most prevalent component of rock to describe a facies in a given volume, rock outcrop, or well interval.

data.Name: Dominant Geological Formation Name
data.Description: Dominant or primary geological formation. Operators may set up a DataQualityRule to demand that the DominantGeologicalFormationName value must match a reference-data--GeologicFormation record's Name property.

data.Name: Dominant Geological Formation ID
data.Description: Dominant or primary name given to a body of rock having a consistent set of physical (litho-stratigraphic), temporal (chrono-stratigraphic) or fossil (bio-stratigraphic) characteristics that distinguishes it from adjacent bodies of rock, and which occupies a particular position in the layers of rock in a geographical region.

data.Name: Dominant Lithology ID
data.Description: Description of its physical characteristics visible at outcrop, in hand or core samples, or with low magnification microscopy. Physical characteristics include colour, texture, grain size, and composition.

data.Name: Dominant Seal Lithology ID
data.Description: The dominant rock type of the sealing lithofacies.

data.Name: Dominant Source Rock Lithology ID
data.Description: The dominant rock type of the source rock lithofacies.

data.Name: Drive Mechanism Type ID
data.Description: The natural and supplemental drive mechanisms for the recovery of reservoir fluids. The drive mechanism is determined by the sources of energy inherent in a reservoir which force reservoir fluids into a completion.

data.Name: Gas Height
data.Description: Vertical distance between the Gas fluid contact and the crest of the reservoir. Hydrocarbon (HC)  column height = Reservoir Depth - Fluid Contact (at the wells).

data.Name: Gas Formation Volume Factor
data.Description: The Formation volume factor of a gas is defined as the ratio of the gas volume in the reservoir at reservoir pressure and temperature to the standard produced volume of gas at the surface.

data.Name: Fault Compartmentalization ID
data.Description: It is an indicator of the degree of Fault Compartmentalization in the reservoir.

data.Name: Sample Acquisition Type ID
data.Description: Refers to "where/how" the sample was captured. Several samples may be taken for the same reservoir at different times and for different purposes. It is to the operators to use this property to indicate the most commonly used method for the specific reservoir.

data.Name: Geological Duration
data.Description: The amount of geologic time (in millions of years) that has passed in any given event for a measured interval.

data.Name: Fracture Density ID
data.Description: It is an indicator of the degree of Fracture density in the reservoir.

data.Name: Thickness True Vertical Gross
data.Description: The true vertical total thickness of the interval, including rock that does not meet the cut-off criteria.

data.Name: Hydrogen Sulphide Content
data.Description: Average Hydrogen Sulfide (H2S mole % in Gas) content in a reservoir or field.

data.Name: Dominant Gas Source Type
data.Description: Indicates the primary source of gas in a reservoir.

data.Name: Geological Age Name
data.Description: Human-friendly label referring to periods of marked change in the processes and events in the entire history of the earth during which a system of rocks formed. Points to specific units in the adopted geological time scale (GTS); for example, the  International Chronostratigraphic Chart. Operators may set up a DataQualityRule to demand that the GeologicAgeName value must match a reference-data--ChronoStratigraphy record's Name property.

data.Name: Geological Age ID
data.Description: Refers to periods of marked change in the processes and events in the entire history of the earth during which a system of rocks formed. Points to specific units in the adopted geological time scale (GTS); for example, the  International Chronostratigraphic Chart.

data.Name: Condensate Gas Ratio Initial Surface Condition
data.Description: Initial CGR is the amount of liquid content of the gas condensate at reservoir temperature and pressures higher than the dew point pressure of the fluid system at the same reservoir temperature. Commonly reported in field unit of stb/mmscf. When the pressure drops below the dew point pressure of the system, some of the liquid content of the gas condensate will drop off.

data.Name: Geobody Interpretation ID
data.Description: Structures in the Earth's crust that have geological causes. Points to one of potentially many geobody interpretations as a single consistent description of a local rock volume feature

data.Name: Geological Structure Type ID
data.Description: Relates to three main type of structure as defined by ResQML caused by deformation in Earth's crust: unconformities, faults and fractures, and folds. We usually think of rocks as being very hard and brittle.

data.Name: Geologic Confidence ID
data.Description: Confidence of the geological interpretation (based on log data, biostratigraphic data context), different from data quality to quantify the risk for an entire basin,  interval, reservoir segment, or field. Technical Assurance for values which do not have technical assurance defined at this time.

data.Name: Gas Oil Ratio Initial Surface Condition
data.Description: Initial GOR is the amount of gas that is dissolved in the oil at reservoir temperature and pressures higher than the bubble point pressure of the fluid system at the same reservoir temperature. Commonly reported in field unit of scf/stb. When the pressure drops below the bubble point pressure of the system, some of the dissolved gas will be evolved/separated.

data.Name: Hc Sub Type ID
data.Description: The types of hydrocarbons present in the reservoir. When there is only one value specified, it represents the dominant hydrocarbon present. When multiple values are specified, the first value represents the dominant hydrocarbon, the next value represents the secondary, and so on.

data.Name: Hc Type ID
data.Description: Use same definition as EstimatedTechnicalVolumes.

data.Name: Horizontal Heterogeneity ID
data.Description: It is an indicator of the degree of horizontal heterogeneity  across the horizontal section of the reservoir.

data.Name: Is Fractured
data.Description: An overall TRUE/FALSE indication of whether the reservoir is considered to be fractured.

data.Name: Is Overpressured
data.Description: When a fluid pressure is higher than estimated from the normal hydrostatic fluid gradient for a given depth, it is called overpressure (wiki.aapg.org).

data.Name: Mercury Injection Capillary Pressure Entry Maximum
data.Description: Refers to the analysis to identify the maximum capillary entry pressure measured by MICP in the basin, model, or area indicating sealing capabilities of the rocks.

data.Name: Methane Content
data.Description: Average Methane (CH4 mole % in Gas) content in a reservoir or field.

data.Name: Lateral Continuity
data.Description: It is an indicator of the lateral continuity of the reservoir.

data.Name: Litho Stratigraphic Hierarchy ID
data.Description: Refers to the organization of rock bodies into units on the basis of their lithologic properties and their stratigraphic relations. Formally identified lithostratigraphic units are structured in a hierarchy of lithostratigraphic rank, higher rank units generally comprising two or more units of lower rank. Going from smaller to larger in rank, the main lithostratigraphic ranks are Bed, Member, Formation, Group and Supergroup.

data.Name: Rock Thickness Source True Stratigraphic Net
data.Description: Average true vertical thickness of the stratigraphic thickness of the total source facies within this lithofacies unit that meets the cut-off criteria.

data.Name: Net To Gross Ratio
data.Description: The Net-to-Gross ratio is the total amount of aggregated net within a reservoir/zone/interval calculated by dividing the net by the total gross thickness.

data.Name: Nitrogen Content
data.Description: Average Nitrogen (N2 mole % in Gas) content in a reservoir or field.

data.Name: Non Reservoir Thickness True Vertical
data.Description: True vertical - same as Non-net Reservoir Thickness in PWLS.

data.Name: Oil Api Gravity
data.Description: At initial oil, the measure of API of oil. API Gravity is a measure of how heavy or light crude-oil is compared to water (density of crude oil / density of water).

data.Name: Oil Height
data.Description: Vertical distance between the Oil- fluid contact and the crest of the reservoir. Hydrocarbon (HC)  column height = Reservoir Depth - Fluid Contact (at the wells).

data.Name: Oil Formation Volume Factor
data.Description: The Formation volume factor Oil (commonly known as Bo), is defined as the ratio of the volume of oil (plus the gas in solution) at the prevailing reservoir temperature and pressure to the volume of oil at standard conditions.

data.Name: Is Organic Oilfield Scale
data.Description: Oilfield scaling is the precipitation and accumulation of insoluble crystals (salts) from a mixture of incompatible aqueous phases in oil processing systems. This is to indicate whether the scale is of organic matter or not as a boolean.

data.Name: Oil Mobility
data.Description: Mobility is defined as the ratio of the permeability of a particular petroleum fluid (either water or oil) to its apparent viscosity. It describes the rate and efficiency of oil displacement by other immiscible fluids.

data.Name: Gas Oil Contact Depth Initial True Vertical
data.Description: True Vertical Depth Subsea to the Gas/Oil contact measured in a discovery well, without any production or injection. Can be used as an indication of the original gas/oil contact for the entire reservoir.

data.Name: Oil Water Contact Depth Initial True Vertical
data.Description: True Vertical Depth Subsea to the Oil/Water contact measured in a discovery well, without any production or injection. Can be used as an indication of the original oil/water contact for the entire reservoir.

data.Name: Overburden Pressure
data.Description: Overburden pressure is the pressure on the rock from the weight of the rock and earth above the formation. When the overburden pressure exceeds the fluid pressure in the pore space, the formation is compacted.

data.Name: Pore Volume
data.Description: The volume of the porosity of the rock; the volume of the rock multiplied by the pore fraction.

data.Name: Pressure Current
data.Description: The reservoir pressure measured or estimated after fluids are produced or injected from/to a reservoir. The Original vs Current pressure can provide an indication of the reservoir depletion. The specific date is not required. Information may be gathered by different means including joint venture data sharing, government agencies or vendors' data packages, etc.

data.Name: Pressure Initial
data.Description:
The reservoir pressure measured in a discovery well, without any production or injection. Can be used as an indication of the original pressure for the entire reservoir.
The specific date is not required. Information may be gathered by different means including joint venture data sharing, government agencies or vendors' data packages, etc.

data.Name: Recovery Factor
data.Description: Recovery factor at certain date derived from Estimated Technical Volumes and Produced Volumes (Work Product Component)

data.Name: Reservoir Thickness True Vertical
data.Description: The true vertical total thickness of the interval, including rock that meets the cut-off criteria.

data.Name: Reservoir Play Type ID
data.Description: A named area that likely contains a combination of certain geological factors making it prospective for mineral exploration. It is often considered to be a set of prospects with a common set of characteristics.

data.Name: Reservoir Quality ID
data.Description: The quality of a reservoir is defined by its hydrocarbon storage capacity and deliverability.

data.Name: Reservoir Tectonic Setting Type ID
data.Description: Tectonic setting refers to the different tectonic conditions present at a particular location and time on Earth. It describes whether somewhere is near a tectonic plate boundary or in a more interior position on the plate.

data.Name: Reservoir Tectonic Stress Regime ID
data.Description: The stress regime relates to tectonic kinematics and is an expression of the relative magnitudes of the stresses acting on the rocks, including reservoirs.

data.Name: Sand Thickness True Vertical
data.Description: The true vertical total thickness of the sand interval.

data.Name: Saturation Pressure
data.Description: The pressure of a vapor which is in equilibrium with its liquid.

data.Name: Seal Thickness True Vertical
data.Description: The true vertical total thickness of the seal interval.

data.Name: Seal Depositional Tectonic Setting Type ID
data.Description: Tectonic setting refers to the different tectonic conditions present at a particular location and time on Earth.

data.Name: Seal Geological Age Name
data.Description: Human friendly label for the geologic age of the seal. Operators may set up a DataQualityRule to demand that the SealGeologicalAgeName value must match a reference-data--ChronoStratigraphy record's Name property.

data.Name: Seal Geological Age ID
data.Description: The reference to the chronostratigraphy record for the seal's age.

data.Name: Sedimentation Rate
data.Description: The rate of sedimentation is the thickness of sediment accumulated per unit time. The unit of measure is fixed to mm/Ma and not subject to normalization.

data.Name: Seal Type ID
data.Description: The type of the seal for the reservoir

data.Name: Secondary Environment Of Deposition ID
data.Description: A depositional environment is the accumulation of chemical, biological, and physical properties and processes associated with the deposition of sediments that lead to a distinctive suite of sedimentary rocks. When there are multiple environments of deposition, it is the second most volumetrically abundant.

data.Name: Seismic Velocity Average
data.Description: The average velocity of propagation of elastic waves in a particular rock.

data.Name: Shale Thickness True Vertical
data.Description: The true vertical total thickness of the shale interval.

data.Name: Sequence Stratigraphic Scale ID
data.Description: SEPM (Society for Sedimentary Geology) formalized hierarchy of scales.

data.Name: Rock Thickness Source True Stratigraphic
data.Description: Average true vertical thickness of the total source facies within this lithofacies unit.

data.Name: Source Rock Depositional Tectonic Setting Type ID
data.Description: Tectonic setting refers to the different tectonic conditions present at a particular location and time on Earth.

data.Name: Source Rock Geological Age Name
data.Description: Human friendly label for the geologic age of the source rock. Operators may set up a DataQualityRule to demand that the SourceRockGeologicalAgeName value must match a reference-data--ChronoStratigraphy record's Name property.

data.Name: Source Rock Geological Age ID
data.Description: The reference to the chronostratigraphy record for the source rock age.

data.Name: Primary Source Rock Kerogen Type ID
data.Description: The main type of kerogen present in a particular rock formation. It depends of the type of organic material that was originally present and also on the degree of heat and pressure it has been subjected to, and the length of time the geological processes ran. Company can decide use if by average or as detailed as needed.

data.Name: Secondary Source Rock Kerogen Type ID
data.Description: The secondary type of kerogen present in a particular rock formation. It depends of the type of organic material that was originally present and also on the degree of heat and pressure it has been subjected to, and the length of time the geological processes ran. Company can decide use if by average or as detailed as needed.

data.Name: Sulphur Content
data.Description: Average Sulphur (S mole % in Gas) content in a reservoir or field.

data.Name: Stratigraphic Unit ID
data.Description: includes Chrono, litho, bio classifications.

data.Name: Temperature Maximum
data.Description: Refers to the highest temperature observed in the fluids or substances within an underground geological formation or reservoir. It can be determined through a combination of data, including downhole temperature measurements, rock properties, and modeling techniques.

data.Name: Temperature Initial
data.Description: The reservoir temperature measured in a discovery well, without any production or injection. Can be used as an indication of the temperature for the entire reservoir.

data.Name: Tertiary Environment Of Deposition ID
data.Description: A depositional environment is the accumulation of chemical, biological, and physical properties and processes associated with the deposition of sediments that lead to a distinctive suite of sedimentary rocks. When there are multiple environments of deposition, it is the third most volumetrically abundant.

data.Name: Rock Thickness Tight True Vertical
data.Description: The true vertical thickness of the tight or non-permeable rocks.

data.Name: Volume Total Bulk
data.Description: The total volume of rock and pore space within the reservoir.

data.Name: Hydrocarbon Height Total
data.Description: Hydrocarbon (HC) column height  is the vertical distance between the Hydrocarbon fluid contact and the crest of the reservoir.

data.Name: Pore Volume Total Initial
data.Description: The best estimate of the original reservoir pore volume at initial conditions.

data.Name: Trapping Mechanism Type ID
data.Description: Trapping is the mechanism by which migration of oil and gas is stopped such that an accumulation of these fluids occurs. The different mechanisms prevent the upward migration of oil and natural gas up through the reservoir rock.

data.Name: Total Organic Carbon Maximum
data.Description: Measured Total Organic Carbon to assess the potential for organic matter to generate hydrocarbons (such as oil and gas) under certain geological and thermal conditions expressed in a ratio of weight percent organic carbon to total rock sample.

data.Name: Stratigraphic Unit Depth Bottom True Vertical
data.Description: Reflects the (averaged) True Vertical Depth to the bottom of the unit

data.Name: Vertical Connectivity ID
data.Description: It is an indicator of the  degree of vertical communication between reservoirs compartments.

data.Name: Vertical Heterogeneity ID
data.Description: It is an indicator of the degree of Vertical Heterogeneity across the vertical section of the reservoir.

data.Name: Stratigraphic Unit Depth Top True Vertical
data.Description: Reflects the (averaged) True Vertical Depth to the top of the unit.

data.Name: Wax Content
data.Description: Average Wax or Paraffinic Waxes content in a reservoir or field.

data.Name: Reservoir Thickness Wet True Vertical
data.Description: The true vertical thickness of reservoir rocks that are filled with brine or water, not filled with hydrocarbons or pay.

data.Name: Operating Environment ID
data.Description: The operational, geographic environment for the GeoLabelSet.
